description: Number of n-digit reversible primes (or emirps) with distinct digits.
example: 13, 17, 31, 37, 71, 73, 79 and 97 are reversible primes (emirps), so a(2)=8.
mathematica: emrpQ[n_]:=Module[{idn=IntegerDigits[n],rev},rev=Reverse[idn];rev!=idn && Max[DigitCount[n]]==1&&PrimeQ[FromDigits[rev]]]; With[{ems=Select[ Prime[ Range[ 51*10^6]],emrpQ]},Join[ {4},Table[Count[ems,_?(IntegerLength[ #] == n&)],{n,2,9}]]] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Nov 29 2014 *)
prog: (Python)from sympy import primerange, isprimedef A003684(n):    return len([p for p in primerange(10**(n-1),10**n)    if len(set(str(p))) == len(str(p)) and isprime(int(str(p)[::-1]))])# _Chai Wah Wu_, Aug 14 2014
author: _Harvey P. Dale_ and _Jud McCranie_
extensions: Typo in example corrected by David Ritterskamp (dritters(AT)usi.edu), Mar 24 2008
